title: Avoid Minimums
statementHtml:
You are given an integer array a1,a2,a3,…,ana1,a2,a3,…,an. Your task is to make all elements of aa equal. In order to do it, you can perform the following operation at most kk times:

What is the maximum number of coins you can earn among all possible ways to make the array equal?
inputSpecHtml:
The first line contains one integer tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000) — the number of test cases. Next, tt cases follow (all cases are independent).

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (2≤n≤3⋅1052≤n≤3⋅105; 1≤k≤10121≤k≤1012) — the size of array aa and the maximum number of operations you can perform.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the array itself.

It's guaranteed that the total sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 3⋅1053⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, if it's impossible to make all elements equal, print −1−1. Otherwise, print the maximum number of coins you can earn while making all elements equal.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, you need at least 1717 operations to make all elements equal (or to get the array [10,10,10][10,10,10]).

In the second test case, you can, for example, increase a3=4a3=4 to 1010, then increase a1=6a1=6 to 1010, after that increase a4=9a4=9 to 1010 and, finally, a2=2a2=2 to 1010. You'll perform 1919 operations and earn (10−4)+(10−6)+(10−9)=11(10−4)+(10−6)+(10−9)=11 coins in total, since increasing the a2a2 from 22 to 1010 won't give you any coins.

In the third test case, you can leave the array unchanged or make all elements equal to 88 — both strategies will give you 00 coins.
